pull.title: build: Use correct variable name
pull.body:
This was overlooked after https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1546.

Also see:
 - https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1600
 - https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/30845
 - https://github.com/hebasto/oss-fuzz/pull/9

<details><summary>Hints</summary>

Make sure to run all tests locally, according to the documentation.

The failure may happen due to a number of reasons, for example:

* Possibly due to a silent merge conflict (the changes in this pull request being
incompatible with the current code in the target branch). If so, make sure to rebase on the latest
commit of the target branch.

* A sanitizer issue, which can only be found by compiling with the sanitizer and running the
  affected test.

* An intermittent issue.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

</details>

events.message:
build: Use correct variables when passing `-fsanitize` to libsecp256k1

This was overlooked after https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1546

events.body: Rebased on top of the merged https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/30845.

This uncovers a bug in the build system: Building with a fuzz engine fails, because the ctime tests are auto-detected in cmake, based on whether or not valgrind-devel is installed or not.

Steps to reproduce:

* Ensure valgrind devel package is installed
* Call `rm -rf ./bld-cmake/ && cmake -B ./bld-cmake -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER='clang' -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER='clang++' -DBUILD_FOR_FUZZING=ON -DSANITIZERS=fuzzer` and observe that the output says "  ctime_tests ......................... ON"
* Call `cmake --build ./bld-cmake/` and observe the build failure:


```
# cmake --build ./bld-cmake/ 
[  1%] Building C object src/secp256k1/src/CMakeFiles/secp256k1_precomputed.dir/precomputed_ecmult.c.o
[  1%] Building C object src/secp256k1/src/CMakeFiles/secp256k1_precomputed.dir/precomputed_ecmult_gen.c.o
[  1%] Built target secp256k1_precomputed
[  1%] Building C object src/secp256k1/src/CMakeFiles/secp256k1.dir/secp256k1.c.o
[  1%] Linking C static library libsecp256k1.a
[  1%] Built target secp256k1
[  1%] Building C object src/secp256k1/src/CMakeFiles/ctime_tests.dir/ctime_tests.c.o
[  2%] Linking C executable ctime_tests
/usr/bin/ld: CMakeFiles/ctime_tests.dir/ctime_tests.c.o: in function `main':
/b-c/src/secp256k1/src/ctime_tests.c:39: multiple definition of `main';  : in function `main':
(.text+0x16): undefined reference to `LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput'
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
gmake[2]: *** [src/secp256k1/src/CMakeFiles/ctime_tests.dir/build.make:98: src/secp256k1/src/ctime_tests] Error 1
gmake[1]: *** [CMakeFiles/Makefile2:1741: src/secp256k1/src/CMakeFiles/ctime_tests.dir/all] Error 2
gmake: *** [Makefile:136: all] Error 2

> This uncovers a bug in the build system: Building with a fuzz engine fails, because the ctime tests are auto-detected in cmake, based on whether or not valgrind-devel is installed or not.

Thanks! I'll submit a fix shortly.

> This uncovers a bug in the build system: Building with a fuzz engine fails, because the ctime tests are auto-detected in cmake, based on whether or not valgrind-devel is installed or not.

Fixed in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/30865.
